review.title: Weighted Positive Binary Decision Diagrams for Exact Probabilistic Inference
review.abstract: Recent work on weighted model counting has been very successfully applied to the problem of probabilistic inference in Bayesian networks. The probability distribution is encoded into a Boolean normal form and compiled to a target language, in order to represent local structure expressed among conditional probabilities more efficiently. We show that further improvements are possible, by exploiting the knowledge that is lost during the encoding phase and incorporating it into a compiler inspired by Satisfiability Modulo Theories. Constraints among variables are used as a background theory, which allows us to optimize the Shannon decomposition. We propose a new language, called Weighted Positive Binary Decision Diagrams, that reduces the cost of probabilistic inference by using this decomposition variant to induce an arithmetic circuit of reduced size.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: In order to reduce the cost of Bayesian inference through Weighted Model Counting (WMC), we have proposed a new canonical language called Weighted Positive Binary Decision Diagram, which provides more concise probability distributions. In addition to practical results on the compilation size for over 30 Bayesian networks, we have also provided theoretical results in which WPBDD-induced logical circuits have been reduced by an average of 60% compared to OBDD-induced circuits.The reduction rule introduced is responsible for an average reduction of 15% among compiled CPTs. These results can be improved even further in the future by finding a better variable sequence facilitated by WPBDDs, since they do not consider probabilities as auxiliary literals, which considerably reduces the search space. We have evaluated the cost of inference compared to OBDD-induced circuits, resulting in 2.5-fold acceleration, and the Juno Tree Acceleration Algorithm, 100000fold.
